Primordial black hole formation by vacuum bubbles

Heling Deng and Alexander Vilenkin Institute of Cosmology, Tufts University, 574 Boston Ave, Medford, MA, 02155 U.S.A.
Abstract

Vacuum bubbles may nucleate during the inflationary epoch and expand, reaching relativistic speeds. After inflation ends, the bubbles are quickly slowed down, transferring their momentum to a shock wave that propagates outwards in the radiation background. The ultimate fate of the bubble depends on its size. Bubbles smaller than certain critical size collapse to ordinary black holes, while in the supercritical case the bubble interior inflates, forming a baby universe, which is connected to the exterior region by a wormhole. The wormhole then closes up, turning into two black holes at its two mouths. We use numerical simulations to find the masses of black holes formed in this scenario, both in subcritical and supercritical regime. The resulting mass spectrum is extremely broad, ranging over many orders of magnitude. For some parameter values, these black holes can serve as seeds for supermassive black holes and may account for LIGO observations.

I Introduction

Primordial black holes (PBHs) are hypothetical black holes formed in the early universe before any nonlinear large scale structure and galaxies. The idea was conceived and developed decades ago Zeldovich ; Hawking:1971ei ; Carr:1974nx , and since then PBHs have received considerable attention, despite the fact that their existence is yet to be supported by observations. Depending on the model, PBH masses can range from as low as the Planck mass (MPl‚àº10‚àí5similar-tosubscriptùëÄPlsuperscript105M_{\rm{Pl}}\sim 10^{-5} g) to many orders of magnitude above the solar mass (M‚äô‚àº1033similar-tosubscriptùëÄdirect-productsuperscript1033M_{\odot}\sim 10^{33} g). By contrast, black holes formed by stellar collapse cannot have mass smaller than M‚äôsubscriptùëÄdirect-productM_{\odot}. Small PBHs (Mbh<1015‚Äã¬†g)subscriptùëÄbhsuperscript1015¬†g(M_{\rm{bh}}<10^{15}\text{ g}) could be sources of Hawking radiation, whereas PBHs with Mbh>1015‚Äã¬†gsubscriptùëÄbhsuperscript1015¬†gM_{\rm{bh}}>10^{15}\text{ g} have been suggested as a candidate for (at least part of) the cold dark matter and as possible seeds of supermassive black holes. Numerous mechanisms of PBH formation have been proposed over the years. In many scenarios (e.g., Carr:1993aq ; GarciaBellido:1996qt ; Yokoyama:1995ex ; Frampton:2010sw ; Clesse:2015wea ), overdensity produced during inflation may overcome pressure and collapse into a black hole after it reenters the horizon during the radiation-dominated era. Other possibilities are related to first-order phase transitions Kodama:1982sf ; Jedamzik:1999am ; Khlopov:1999ys , the collapse of cosmic string loops Hawking:1987bn ; Polnarev:1988dh ; Garriga:1992nm and domain walls Garriga:1992nm ; Khlopov:2004sc ; GVZ ; DGV , etc.

In this paper, we shall use numerical simulations to explore the possibility, recently suggested in GVZ , that PBH could be formed by nonperturbative quantum effects in the early universe. Specifically, we will show that spontaneous nucleation of vacuum bubbles during the inflationary epoch can result in black holes with a wide mass spectrum at the present time.

The physical mechanism responsible for this phenomenon is easy to understand. The inflationary expansion of the universe is driven by the high energy density œÅisubscriptùúåùëñ\rho_{i} of the false vacuum 111We use the term "false vacuum" somewhat loosely, including a slowly rolling inflaton in this category.. Bubble nucleation may occur by quantum tunneling if the underlying physics includes some vacuum states, other than our present vacuum, with energy density œÅb<œÅisubscriptùúåbsubscriptùúåùëñ\rho_{\rm{b}}<\rho_{i} (we will be interested in the case where œÅb>0subscriptùúåb0\rho_{\rm{b}}>0). A two-dimensional energy landscape corresponding to this setup is illustrated in Fig. 1. The inflaton field slowly "rolls" along the gentle slope in the landscape towards a local energy density minimum representing our vacuum. As it rolls, it can tunnel through a potential barrier to another vacuum of energy density higher than ours. The tunneling occurs through bubble nucleation: a small spherical bubble of the new vacuum spontaneously forms in the inflating background Coleman:1980aw . Once the bubble nucleates, it expands with acceleration, acquiring a large Lorentz factor. This growth of the bubble is caused by the large vacuum tension outside (which is greater than the vacuum tension inside). At the end of inflation, the false vacuum outside the bubble decays into hot radiation. The bubble wall runs into the radiation and quickly loses much of its energy, producing a shock wave that propagates outwards. A black hole is then formed by one of the two different scenarios, depending on the size of the bubble. (i) The bubble wall is pulled inwards by the interior vacuum tension, the wall tension, as well as the radiation pressure; so it shrinks and eventually collapses to a singularity. Following GVZ , we shall refer to such bubbles as subcritical. (ii) If in the course of bubble expansion its size exceeds the interior de Sitter horizon, the bubble begins to inflate. In the latter case, the bubble continues to expand without bound and a wormhole is created outside the bubble wall, connecting the inflating baby universe inside and the FRW parent universe dominated by radiation. Such bubbles will be called supercritical.

It was argued in Ref.¬†GVZ that the bubble transfers most of its kinetic energy to surrounding matter and comes to rest with respect to the Hubble flow on a time scale much shorter than the Hubble time. If the exterior region were filled with pressureless dust, an empty layer would form around the bubble, so the bubble would be completely isolated from matter. In this case the bubble evolution and the mass of the resulting black hole can be found analytically. The case with a radiation background is more involved, due to the pressure exerted on the wall. Also, if a wormhole is formed, some radiation may follow the bubble into the wormhole. Both of these effects may influence the black hole mass.

Our goal in this paper is to numerically study black hole formation by vacuum bubbles and to determine the resulting spectrum of black hole masses. The paper is organized as follows. In Section II we discuss the bubble dynamics in more detail and review some relevant earlier work. Our simulation model is described in Section III, and simulation results are presented in Section IV. We calculate the black hole mass spectrum in Section V and discuss observational implications and constraints on the model parameters in Section VI. Our conclusions are summarized and discussed in Section VII. We set c=‚Ñè=1ùëêPlanck-constant-over-2-pi1c=\hbar=1 throughout the paper.

II Bubble dynamics

We consider an idealized model where inflation ends instantaneously at time t=tiùë°subscriptùë°ùëñt=t_{i}, so that false vacuum outside the bubble is instantly turned into radiation of initial energy density œÅisubscriptùúåùëñ\rho_{i}. We also assume, as in Ref.¬†GVZ , that particles are reflected from the bubble wall, so radiation cannot penetrate the bubble and the bubble interior always remains pure de Sitter.

As we mentioned in the Introduction, the bubble evolution can lead to two possible outcomes, depending on the bubble size. We first consider subcritical bubbles.

II.1 Subcritical bubbles

When the bubble transfers its momentum to radiation and comes to rest with respect to the Hubble flow at t‚âàtiùë°subscriptùë°ùëñt\approx t_{i}, it continues to expand by inertia. But the forces due to the tension of the vacuum inside the bubble and due to the tension of the bubble wall are both directed inwards, so the bubble wall accelerates inwards, away from the surrounding radiation, and we can expect that in a few Hubble times the interaction of the bubble with radiation becomes negligible.

In the subcritical case, the bubble eventually stops expanding and collapses to a Schwarzschild singularity; the corresponding conformal diagram is shown in Fig. 2. We can estimate the mass of the resulting black hole by assuming that the interaction with radiation is negligible right after the initial momentum transfer at t‚âàtiùë°subscriptùë°ùëñt\approx t_{i}. Then the bubble dynamics is the same as it would be if the exterior region were asymptotically Minkowski. The choice of parameters in our simulations was dictated mostly by the computing constraints.

We do not expect the estimates (1) and (4) to be very accurate. Radiation does work on the bubble while it expands (which decreases the bubble mass) and while it contracts (which increases the bubble mass). Since the radiation density is higher during the expanding phase, one can expect the overall effect to be mass reduction (except in cases where the expanding phase is very short). But since the contact with radiation effectively ceases within a few Hubble times, it was suggested in GVZ that Eqs.¬†(1) and (4) should give the right order of magnitude. We shall see that this is indeed the case.

II.2 Supercritical bubbles

For ‚Ñ≥b>Mcrsubscript‚Ñ≥bsubscriptùëÄcr{\cal M}_{\rm{b}}>M_{\rm{cr}}, the bubble expands to a radius greater than Hb‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùêªb1H_{\rm{b}}^{-1}, and the bubble interior begins to inflate. At this point nothing can stop it from growing333For HœÉ>HbsubscriptùêªùúésubscriptùêªbH_{\sigma}>H_{\rm{b}}, the bubble wall starts inflating, due to its repulsive gravity, when its radius exceeds HœÉ‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùêªùúé1H_{\sigma}^{-1}. Inflation in the bubble interior begins when the wall expands to Rw>Hb‚àí1subscriptùëÖwsuperscriptsubscriptùêªb1R_{\rm{w}}>H_{\rm{b}}^{-1}.. In this ‚Äúsupercritical‚Äù case, the bubble grows into a baby universe, which is connected to the parent universe outside by a wormhole throat. The wormhole closes up on a timescale t‚àºG‚ÄãMbhsimilar-toùë°ùê∫subscriptùëÄbht\sim GM_{\rm{bh}}, and black holes of mass Mbh>McrsubscriptùëÄbhsubscriptùëÄcrM_{\rm{bh}}>M_{\rm{cr}} are formed at its two mouths. From then on, the baby universe has no impact on further evolution of the exterior FRW region. The corresponding spacetime structure was discussed in Ref.¬†GVZ ; it is illustrated in the conformal diagram in Fig. 3. As emphasized in GVZ , wormhole formation in this spacetime does not violate any singularity theorems and does not require violation of the null energy condition.

An unusual feature of the diagram in Fig. 3 is the presence of a white hole region (marked WH), as in the Kruskal spacetime of an eternal black hole. The boundaries of black and white holes are usually defined by their event horizons, and we adopted this convention in the figure. A more physically motivated definition is to use apparent (or trapping) horizons (see e.g. Ref. VF and references therein). We followed this approach in our simulations; see Sec. III.D for more detail.

The shock wave produced by the bubble wall propagates outwards at the speed of sound; its trajectory is shown by a dashed curve in the diagram. The region outside the shock remains unperturbed and is described by the FRW solution. On the other hand, the evolution inside the shock radius can be rather complicated. In particular, some radiation flows out of the white hole region, resulting in a decrease of the black hole mass. This can be thought of as an inverse process of radiation flowing into a black hole, which would increase the mass.

A related problem has been studied in Ref.¬†DGV , which investigated the collapse of spherical domain walls formed during inflation. In this case, inflation ends both inside and outside the wall. If the wall expands to a radius greater than HœÉ‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùêªùúé1H_{\sigma}^{-1}, it starts inflating and a radiation-filled baby universe is formed. It was pointed out in DGV that the Schwarzschild radius of the resulting black hole cannot exceed the radius of the comoving FRW region affected by the wall when it comes within the cosmological horizon. The affected region is marked by the rarefaction wave that propagates away from the wall at the speed of sound. The resulting bound on the black hole mass is

G‚ÄãMbh<2.8‚ÄãHi‚ÄãRi2.ùê∫subscriptùëÄbh2.8subscriptùêªùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëÖùëñ2GM_{\rm{bh}}<2.8H_{i}R_{i}^{2}. (6)

The situation in our case is very similar, except the affected region is now bounded by the shock front. Hence we expect the same bound to apply. Numerical simulations in Ref.¬†DGV showed that black hole masses in supercritical regime are G‚ÄãMbh‚àºHi‚ÄãRi2similar-toùê∫subscriptùëÄbhsubscriptùêªùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëÖùëñ2GM_{\rm{bh}}\sim H_{i}R_{i}^{2}, so the bound (6) is nearly saturated. Here, we shall see that the same conclusion applies to supercritical bubbles with a sufficiently large RisubscriptùëÖùëñR_{i}.

III Simulation setup

In this section we consider the equations of motion as well as the initial and boundary conditions necessary for numerical simulations of a vacuum bubble embedded in an otherwise homogeneous radiation-dominated universe. We also indicate how we read the black hole mass from the simulation results and discuss some simulation issues.

III.1 Equations of motion and gauge conditions

The spacetime is assumed to be spherically symmetric, and the metric we use for the exterior region (outside of the bubble) is

In this gauge, both the equations of motion and the boundary conditions take a particularly simple form. Since the fluid is confined to the bubble exterior, the normal component of the fluid velocity vanishes at the bubble wall. The tangential velocity vanishes by symmetry. It follows that the wall is comoving with the fluid; hence it remains at a fixed value of the comoving radius, r=rwùëüsubscriptùëüwr=r_{\rm w}. With a different choice of gauge we would have to impose boundary conditions on a moving boundary, which is considerably more complicated.

Eqs.¬†(14) and (15) can be written in an equivalent form:

BÀô=A‚ÄãBU‚Äã(4‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÅ‚ÄãR‚àíMR2+Œì‚Ä≤B),Àôùêµùê¥ùêµùëà4ùúãùúåùëÖùëÄsuperscriptùëÖ2superscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùêµ\dot{B}=\frac{AB}{U}\left(4\pi\rho R-\frac{M}{R^{2}}+\frac{\Gamma^{\prime}}{B}\right), (17)
œÅÀô=‚àí(1+w)‚ÄãœÅ‚ÄãAU‚Äã(4‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÅ‚ÄãR‚àíMR2+Œì‚Ä≤B+2‚ÄãU2R).Àôùúå1ùë§ùúåùê¥ùëà4ùúãùúåùëÖùëÄsuperscriptùëÖ2superscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùêµ2superscriptùëà2ùëÖ\dot{\rho}=-(1+w)\frac{\rho A}{U}\left(4\pi\rho R-\frac{M}{R^{2}}+\frac{\Gamma^{\prime}}{B}+\frac{2U^{2}}{R}\right). (18)

We used different equations in different situations in order to avoid a vanishing denominator. For instance, in the subcritical case, the bubble grows and then shrinks, so the value of UùëàU at the wall goes from positive to negative at the turning point. Hence we use Eqs.¬†(14) and (15) to evolve BùêµB and œÅùúå\rho respectively, since U=0ùëà0U=0 must not appear in the denominator. Similarly, in the supercritical case, ŒìŒì\Gamma crosses zero when the wormhole throat is formed, so we use Eqs.¬†(17) and (18).

The gauge condition u1=0superscriptùë¢10u^{1}=0 leaves the freedom of time transformations, t‚Üít¬Ø‚Äã(t)‚Üíùë°¬Øùë°ùë°t\to{\bar{t}}(t). We can fix the gauge completely by specifying A‚Äã(r,t)ùê¥ùëüùë°A(r,t) on any timelike curve. Before the bubble is removed for reasons discussed below (Subsection IV.B), a convenient choice is to set A‚Äã(rw,t)=1ùê¥subscriptùëüwùë°1A(r_{\rm w},t)=1 at the bubble wall. Then our time coordinate tùë°t coincides with the proper time œÑùúè\tau at the wall.

III.2 Boundary conditions

We first comment on the number of boundary conditions required for our problem. The following argument was suggested to us by Andrei Gruzinov.

Introducing two new variables, C=A3/Bùê∂superscriptùê¥3ùêµC=A^{3}/B and F=Œì2‚àíU2ùêπsuperscriptŒì2superscriptùëà2F=\Gamma^{2}-U^{2}, instead of BùêµB and ŒìŒì\Gamma, the equations of motion (11)-(15) can be represented as

UÀô=‚àíw1+w‚ÄãA‚ÄãŒìB‚ÄãœÅ‚ÄãœÅ‚Ä≤+‚Ä¶,Àôùëàùë§1ùë§ùê¥Œìùêµùúåsuperscriptùúå‚Ä≤‚Ä¶{\dot{U}}=-\frac{w}{1+w}\frac{A\Gamma}{B\rho}\rho^{\prime}+...~{}, (20)
œÅÀô=‚àí(1+w)‚ÄãA‚ÄãœÅB‚ÄãŒì‚ÄãU‚Ä≤+‚Ä¶,Àôùúå1ùë§ùê¥ùúåùêµŒìsuperscriptùëà‚Ä≤‚Ä¶{\dot{\rho}}=-(1+w)\frac{A\rho}{B\Gamma}U^{\prime}+...~{}, (21)

where "‚Ä¶" means terms without derivatives and we have used Eq.¬†(10) to express A‚Ä≤superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤A^{\prime} in terms of œÅ‚Ä≤superscriptùúå‚Ä≤\rho^{\prime} in (20). Now, Eqs.¬†(19) do not require boundary conditions (only initial conditions) and Eqs.¬†(20) and (21) represent a wave with a (high-frequency) sound speed cs2=w‚ÄãA2/B2superscriptsubscriptùëêùë†2ùë§superscriptùê¥2superscriptùêµ2c_{s}^{2}=wA^{2}/B^{2}. We thus have one propagating degree of freedom, which requires one left and one right boundary condition.

Variables outside of the shock front should be described by the unperturbed FRW solution, so the outer boundary condition is easy to impose. Before the bubble is removed, the wall serves as the inner boundary. The bubble interior is described by de Sitter space with energy density œÅbsubscriptùúåb\rho_{\rm{b}}. The boundary conditions at the wall can be obtained using Israel‚Äôs junction conditions. This is done in Appendix A.444The equation of motion of the wall is also derived in Appendix A, but we did not use it in our simulations. As we discussed, we only need one boundary condition at r=rwùëüsubscriptùëüwr=r_{\rm w}; we use the condition (69):

A‚Ä≤=‚àíA‚ÄãB‚Äã(w‚ÄãœÅ+œÅbœÉ+2‚ÄãŒìR+6‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÉ).superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤ùê¥ùêµùë§ùúåsubscriptùúåbùúé2ŒìùëÖ6ùúãùúéA^{\prime}=-AB\left(\frac{w\rho+\rho_{\rm{b}}}{\sigma}+\frac{2\Gamma}{R}+6\pi\sigma\right). (22)

We also set A=1ùê¥1A=1 on the inner boundary at all times, even after the bubble wall is removed.

III.3 Initial conditions

We assume an idealized initial state where inflation ends instantaneously at t=tiùë°subscriptùë°ùëñt=t_{i} and false vacuum energy immediately turns into radiation of uniform energy density

œÅi=332‚ÄãœÄ‚Äãti2=38‚ÄãœÄ.subscriptùúåùëñ332ùúãsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëñ238ùúã\rho_{i}=\frac{3}{32\pi t_{i}^{2}}=\frac{3}{8\pi}. (23)

Since the lapse function A=1ùê¥1A=1 at r=rwùëüsubscriptùëüwr=r_{\rm w}, it follows from Eq.¬†(10) that A‚Äã(r,ti)=1ùê¥ùëüsubscriptùë°ùëñ1A(r,t_{i})=1 in the entire region outside of the bubble. One might expect that at t=tiùë°subscriptùë°ùëñt=t_{i} this whole region is described by the FRW solution. Then, with a suitable normalization of rùëür, we would have B‚Äã(r,ti)=1ùêµùëüsubscriptùë°ùëñ1B(r,t_{i})=1, R‚Äã(r,ti)=rùëÖùëüsubscriptùë°ùëñùëüR(r,t_{i})=r, U‚Äã(r,ti)=r/2‚Äãtiùëàùëüsubscriptùë°ùëñùëü2subscriptùë°ùëñU(r,t_{i})=r/2t_{i}, and Œì‚Äã(r,ti)=1Œìùëüsubscriptùë°ùëñ1\Gamma(r,t_{i})=1. However, these values cannot be imposed as initial conditions in the entire region r>rwùëüsubscriptùëüwr>r_{\rm w}.

At the initial moment, the bubble wall moving with a large Lorentz factor comes into contact with the radiation fluid that surrounds it. On the other hand, we are working in a gauge where the radiation is comoving with the wall at r=rwùëüsubscriptùëüwr=r_{\rm w}. Clearly, this condition cannot be satisfied if the FRW solution outside the bubble is unperturbed. We deal with this problem by modifying the FRW solution in a thin layer around the bubble.

A profile of U‚Äã(r,ti)ùëàùëüsubscriptùë°ùëñU(r,t_{i}) with a finite Œ¥ùõø\delta means that the fluid already acquired some kinetic energy at tisubscriptùë°ùëñt_{i} in a layer of width Œ¥ùõø\delta. It is shown in Ref.¬†GVZ that the wall loses most of its kinetic energy and comes to rest with respect to the radiation fluid within a time Œî‚Äãt‚àºHœÉ2/Hi3similar-toŒîùë°superscriptsubscriptùêªùúé2superscriptsubscriptùêªùëñ3\Delta t\sim H_{\sigma}^{2}/H_{i}^{3} (a more accurate calculation gives Œî‚Äãt‚àº100‚ÄãHœÉ2/Hi3similar-toŒîùë°100superscriptsubscriptùêªùúé2superscriptsubscriptùêªùëñ3\Delta t\sim 100H_{\sigma}^{2}/H_{i}^{3}). This suggests that Œ¥ùõø\delta should be chosen so that Œ¥‚â≤Œî‚Äãtless-than-or-similar-toùõøŒîùë°\delta\lesssim\Delta t. Indeed, we have verified that reducing Œ¥ùõø\delta below this value does not have a significant impact on the black hole mass.

III.4 Expansions and horizons

We determine the formation of a black hole by checking if an apparent horizon bounding a trapped region is formed. Let ŒòoutsubscriptŒòout\Theta_{\rm{out}} and ŒòinsubscriptŒòin\Theta_{\rm{in}} be the expansions of outgoing and ingoing radial null geodesics respectively; then a surface is trapped if Œòout,Œòin<0subscriptŒòoutsubscriptŒòin0\Theta_{\rm{out}},\Theta_{\rm{in}}<0, and anti-trapped if Œòout,Œòin>0subscriptŒòoutsubscriptŒòin0\Theta_{\rm{out}},\Theta_{\rm{in}}>0. In our coordinate system numerical R ,

Œòout‚àùU+ŒìR,Œòin‚àùU‚àíŒìR.formulae-sequenceproportional-tosubscriptŒòoutùëàŒìùëÖproportional-tosubscriptŒòinùëàŒìùëÖ\Theta_{\rm{out}}\propto\frac{U+\Gamma}{R},\ \Theta_{\rm{in}}\propto\frac{U-\Gamma}{R}. (29)

The apparent horizon of a black hole is foliated by marginal spheres with Œòout=0subscriptŒòout0\Theta_{\rm{out}}=0 and Œòin<0.subscriptŒòin0\Theta_{\rm{in}}<0. We also define the white hole (apparent) horizon and cosmological (apparent) horizon to be hypersurfaces foliated by marginal spheres with Œòin=0subscriptŒòin0\Theta_{\rm{in}}=0 and Œòout>0.subscriptŒòout0\Theta_{\rm{out}}>0. A spherical surface is anti-trapped within the white hole horizon, and is normal (with Œòin>0subscriptŒòin0\Theta_{\rm{in}}>0 and Œòout>0subscriptŒòout0\Theta_{\rm{out}}>0) if it lies between the white (or black hole) and the cosmological horizon. The cosmological horizon and the Hubble radius coincide in a flat FRW universe.

III.5 Simulation issues

We use finite-difference method and Runge-Kutta integration to solve the PDEs.

Special attention is needed on the shock wave. The shock formed by the interaction of the fast-moving wall and the radiation may lead to numerical instability. A standard and convenient trick to handle this is to introduce artificial viscosity VonNeumann in order to smooth out the discontinuity. Following LRT , we add an extra term to wùë§w,

w‚Üí13+Œ≤‚ÄãŒî‚Äãr2‚Äã(U‚Ä≤R‚Ä≤+2‚ÄãUR‚àí|U‚Ä≤R‚Ä≤+2‚ÄãUR|)‚Äã(U‚Ä≤R‚Ä≤‚àíUR),‚Üíùë§13ùõΩŒîsuperscriptùëü2superscriptùëà‚Ä≤superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤2ùëàùëÖsuperscriptùëà‚Ä≤superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤2ùëàùëÖsuperscriptùëà‚Ä≤superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤ùëàùëÖw\to\frac{1}{3}+\beta\Delta r^{2}\left(\frac{U^{\prime}}{R^{\prime}}+\frac{2U}{R}-\left|\frac{U^{\prime}}{R^{\prime}}+\frac{2U}{R}\right|\right)\left(\frac{U^{\prime}}{R^{\prime}}-\frac{U}{R}\right), (30)

where Œ≤ùõΩ\beta is an adjustable coefficient that controls the viscosity strength, and Œî‚ÄãrŒîùëü\Delta r is the grid size. When needed, we replace U‚Ä≤/R‚Ä≤superscriptùëà‚Ä≤superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤U^{\prime}/R^{\prime} by

U‚Ä≤R‚Ä≤‚ÜíU‚àí1‚Äã(4‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÅ‚ÄãR‚àíMR2+Œì‚Ä≤B)‚Üísuperscriptùëà‚Ä≤superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤superscriptùëà14ùúãùúåùëÖùëÄsuperscriptùëÖ2superscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùêµ\frac{U^{\prime}}{R^{\prime}}\to U^{-1}\left(4\pi\rho R-\frac{M}{R^{2}}+\frac{\Gamma^{\prime}}{B}\right) (31)

to avoid R‚Ä≤=0superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤0R^{\prime}=0 in the denominator in Eq. (30).

Additionally, in order to improve the efficiency of the code, we use an adaptive non-uniform mesh. At the beginning of the simulation, a sufficiently high resolution is used until a shock wave is formed. Then we reduce the mesh density in regions far away from the shock. We keep track of the shock and make sure there is a sufficient number of grid points there.

Another issue is related to the early evolution of the bubble wall. A very large initial Lorentz factor Œ≥ùõæ\gamma tends to break down the code before any desirable results are obtained. Throughout the simulations we used Œ≥‚â≤10less-than-or-similar-toùõæ10\gamma\lesssim 10. This leads to a constraint on HœÉsubscriptùêªùúéH_{\sigma}. The initial Lorentz factor can be estimated as GVZ Œ≥‚àºHœÉ‚àí1similar-toùõæsuperscriptsubscriptùêªùúé1\gamma\sim H_{\sigma}^{-1}. Using this and Eqs.¬†(4) and (5), it can be shown that the radii of subcritical bubbles must satisfy Ri‚â≤Œ≥less-than-or-similar-tosubscriptùëÖùëñùõæR_{i}\lesssim\gamma. On the other hand, we are mostly interested in bubbles of initial radius greater than the horizon, Ri‚â≥1greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptùëÖùëñ1R_{i}\gtrsim 1. This gives a rather limited range of values for RisubscriptùëÖùëñR_{i}. For supercritical bubbles, we are free to use a large value for RisubscriptùëÖùëñR_{i}, but are restricted by the simulation runtime.

IV Simulation results

IV.1 Shock propagation

The formation and propagation of the shock wave produced by the bubble are illustrated in Fig. 5. The figure shows the radiation density profile at successive moments of time. As the bubble wall hits the ambient radiation, a thin overdense layer is formed right outside the wall. In this example, the density in the layer exceeds that in the FRW region by more than 100 times. The overdense layer spreads and develops a sharp shock front, which then propagates outwards. Meanwhile, the radiation density next to the wall rapidly drops, and in less than a Hubble time becomes much smaller than that in the FRW region.

The density contrast across the shock Œ¥s‚â°Œî‚ÄãœÅ/œÅFRWsubscriptùõøùë†ŒîùúåsubscriptùúåFRW\delta_{s}\equiv\Delta\rho/\rho_{\rm{FRW}}, where Œî‚ÄãœÅ‚â°œÅshock‚àíœÅFRWŒîùúåsubscriptùúåshocksubscriptùúåFRW\Delta\rho\equiv\rho_{\rm{shock}}-\rho_{\rm{FRW}}, is very large immediately after the wall hits the ambient radiation, but rapidly drops and becomes ùí™‚Äã(1)ùí™1{\cal O}(1) in about a Hubble time. Fig. 6 shows the subsequent evolution of Œ¥ssubscriptùõøùë†\delta_{s}, which can be approximated as Œ¥s‚Äã(t)‚àùt‚àí1/2proportional-tosubscriptùõøùë†ùë°superscriptùë°12\delta_{s}(t)\propto t^{-1/2}.

As the shock propagates outwards, the empty layer created by the bubble impact is gradually filled with radiation. In Fig. 7 we show the radiation density profile at several moments right before and after black hole formation, both for a subcritical and a supercritical bubble. In both cases, in a few Hubble times after the black hole is formed, it is surrounded by a nearly uniform radiation background.

IV.2 Black hole mass

IV.2.1 Subcritical bubble

The Misner-Sharp mass of the bubble decreases dramatically within a time scale Œî‚Äãt‚â™timuch-less-thanŒîùë°subscriptùë°ùëñ\Delta t\ll t_{i} due to momentum transfer to radiation. At later times, the mass continues to change due to the radiation pressure, but it approaches a constant after about one Hubble time (Fig. 8). In the subcritical case, the bubble radius RwsubscriptùëÖwR_{\rm{w}} reaches a maximum and then decreases. An apparent horizon is formed when Œòout=0subscriptŒòout0\Theta_{\rm{out}}=0 at the wall. We regard this as a signal of black hole formation. The black hole mass can be estimated as the Misner-Sharp mass at the apparent horizon.

The black hole masses obtained from the simulations are compared with the analytic estimate (4) in Table. 1. We see that Eq.¬†(4) gives a good estimate within a factor of 2. As expected, in most examples the actual black hole mass is lower than estimated, because of the radiation pressure during the expansion phase of the bubble. In some examples, however, the actual mass is slightly higher. This is because the expansion phase in these cases was very short.

At later times, the black hole mass grows by accretion of radiation, but the resulting mass increase is no more than by a factor of 2 DGV .

IV.2.2 Supercritical bubble

In the supercritical case, a wormhole develops outside of the bubble wall, and the bubble starts to inflate. In Fig. 9 we show the area radius RùëÖR as a function of the comoving radius rùëür at several successive moments of time. We see that R‚Äã(r)ùëÖùëüR(r) develops a minimum outside of the wall, signaling the formation of a wormhole. Since the bubble is rapidly expanding, the radius R‚Äã(r)ùëÖùëüR(r) grows sharply towards the wall.

In order to simulate the evolution of the region near the bubble wall, high resolution is needed. However, since the bubble grows supersonically away from the exterior region and thus gets detached from the fluid, we cut off the wall as well as a layer immediately outside, so as to prevent R‚Äã(r)ùëÖùëüR(r) from changing steeply near the inner boundary and avoid simulation breakdown. This excision does not affect the evolution of the exterior region.

The black hole formation is signaled by the horizon bifurcation point, where Œòout=Œòin=0subscriptŒòoutsubscriptŒòin0\Theta_{\rm{out}}=\Theta_{\rm{in}}=0. (This is the point at the intersection of the two apparent horizon lines in the conformal diagram of Fig. 3.) At this point two black holes of equal mass are formed, one for the observer in the baby universe and the other in the exterior FRW universe.

The two black holes start with identical masses, but the masses can grow later by accretion and do not have to remain equal. The mass accretion on the exterior black hole has been studied in Ref.¬†DGV in the domain wall scenario, with the conclusion that it increases the black hole mass by approximately a factor of 2. For a large supercritical bubble, the perturbation caused by the shock should mostly dissipate by the time of black hole formation, and we expect that the accretion process will be very similar to the domain wall case, with similar result.

In Fig.¬†10 we plotted the ratio Mbh/MPl2‚ÄãHi‚ÄãRi2subscriptùëÄbhsuperscriptsubscriptùëÄPl2subscriptùêªùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëÖùëñ2M_{\rm{bh}}/M_{{\rm Pl}}^{2}H_{i}R_{i}^{2} for a range of values of RisubscriptùëÖùëñR_{i}. We see that as RisubscriptùëÖùëñR_{i} increases, the ratio approaches a constant ùí™‚Äã(1)ùí™1{\cal O}(1),

Mbh‚àºMPl2‚ÄãHi‚ÄãRi2.similar-tosubscriptùëÄbhsuperscriptsubscriptùëÄPl2subscriptùêªùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëÖùëñ2M_{\rm{{\rm bh}}}\sim M_{{\rm Pl}}^{2}H_{i}R_{i}^{2}. (32)

Thus, for large values of RisubscriptùëÖùëñR_{i} the bound (6) is nearly saturated, as in the domain wall scenario.

The data points with Ri<Hi‚àí1subscriptùëÖùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùêªùëñ1R_{i}<H_{i}^{-1} correspond to subcritical regime, where we expect Mbh‚àºŒ∫‚ÄãMPl2‚ÄãRi3similar-tosubscriptùëÄbhùúÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëÄPl2superscriptsubscriptùëÖùëñ3M_{\rm{bh}}\sim\kappa M_{\rm{Pl}}^{2}R_{i}^{3} with Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa defined from Eq.(4),

V Black hole mass spectrum

In earlier sections we have shown how a black hole could be formed by a vacuum bubble after inflation and how its mass is related to the initial bubble radius RisubscriptùëÖùëñR_{i}. During inflation the universe expands by a huge factor, so the bubble radii spread over a large range of scales. In this section we calculate the distribution of RisubscriptùëÖùëñR_{i} and find the resulting PBH mass spectrum. The calculation follows closely that in Ref.¬†GVZ .

V.1 Size distribution of bubbles

To simplify the notation, in this subsection we use RùëÖR to denote the bubble radius during inflation.

The background spacetime during inflation can be described by a flat de Sitter metric,

If the first term dominates, f‚Äã(M)‚àùM4/3proportional-toùëìùëÄsuperscriptùëÄ43f(M)\propto M^{4/3}; if the second term dominates, then f‚Äã(M)‚àùM3/2proportional-toùëìùëÄsuperscriptùëÄ32f(M)\propto M^{3/2}. In either case, the mass function decreases relatively fast at M<MHùëÄsubscriptùëÄùêªM<M_{H}, and thus MHsubscriptùëÄùêªM_{H} plays the role of a lower cutoff for the distribution (48).

Another cutoff mechanism is due to shape fluctuations of the bubbles.555We are grateful to Jaume Garriga for emphasizing this to us. At the time of nucleation, bubbles are not perfectly spherical, because of quantum fluctuations. The amplitude of these fluctuations and their subsequent evolution have been discussed in Refs.¬†GV91 ; GV92 . When a subcritical bubble collapses, the shape fluctuations grow and may become large before the bubble shrinks to its Schwarzschild radius. The bubble will then fragment into smaller pieces, which will in turn disintegrate into relativistic particles, so no black hole will be formed. We show in Appendix B that the corresponding lower bound on the black hole mass is

Mbh‚â≥œÅb‚Äã(œÅi‚ÄãMPlœÅb‚ÄãœÉ)3/2‚â°MF.greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptùëÄbhsubscriptùúåbsuperscriptsubscriptùúåùëñsubscriptùëÄPlsubscriptùúåbùúé32subscriptùëÄùêπM_{\rm bh}\gtrsim\rho_{\rm b}\left(\frac{\rho_{i}M_{\rm Pl}}{\rho_{\rm b}\sigma}\right)^{3/2}\equiv M_{F}. (51)

Some black holes with Mbh<MFsubscriptùëÄbhsubscriptùëÄùêπM_{\rm bh}<M_{F} may still be formed from bubbles with atypically small shape fluctuations. We have not explored the mass distribution in this regime.

The shape fluctuations have no effect on the evolution of supercritical bubbles, thus the lower bound cannot be larger than McrsubscriptùëÄcrM_{\rm cr}. Therefore, the mass function (48) is effectively cut off at

Mmin‚àº{max‚Å°{MH,MF},MF<McrMcr,MF>Mcr.similar-tosubscriptùëÄmincasessubscriptùëÄùêªsubscriptùëÄùêπsubscriptùëÄùêπsubscriptùëÄcrsubscriptùëÄcrsubscriptùëÄùêπsubscriptùëÄcrM_{{\rm min}}\sim\begin{cases}\max\{M_{H},M_{F}\},&M_{F}<M_{\rm cr}\\ M_{\rm cr},&M_{F}>M_{\rm cr}\end{cases}. (52)

Depending on the microphysical energy scales œÅisubscriptùúåùëñ\rho_{i} and œÅbsubscriptùúåb\rho_{\rm b}, the mass parameters M‚àósubscriptùëÄM_{*} and MminsubscriptùëÄminM_{\rm min} can take a very wide range of values. For example, with œÅisubscriptùúåùëñ\rho_{i} and œÅbsubscriptùúåb\rho_{\rm b} varying between the electroweak and grand unification scale, M‚àósubscriptùëÄM_{*} can be as small as a few grams and can be larger than the mass of the entire observable universe, while MminsubscriptùëÄminM_{\rm min} is restricted to Mmin‚â≤10‚àí4‚ÄãM‚äôless-than-or-similar-tosubscriptùëÄminsuperscript104subscriptùëÄdirect-productM_{\rm min}\lesssim 10^{-4}M_{\odot}. On the other hand, if the scale of œÅbsubscriptùúåb\rho_{\rm b} is less than the electroweak scale, MminsubscriptùëÄminM_{\rm min} can be much larger. Here we shall treat M‚àósubscriptùëÄM_{*} and MminsubscriptùëÄminM_{\rm min} as free parameters. A general form of the mass function is illustrated in Fig, 11.

By Eq. (44), the total mass fraction of dark matter in PBH is given by

fPBH‚àºB‚ÄãŒª‚Äã(‚Ñ≥eqM‚àó)1/2‚Äã[ln‚Å°(M‚àóMmin)+1].similar-tosubscriptùëìPBHùêµùúÜsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñ≥eqsubscriptùëÄ12delimited-[]subscriptùëÄsubscriptùëÄmin1f_{{\rm PBH}}\sim B\lambda\left(\frac{{\cal M}_{{\rm eq}}}{M_{*}}\right)^{1/2}\left[\ln\left(\frac{M_{*}}{M_{{\rm min}}}\right)+1\right]. (53)

VI Observational properties and constraints

Apart from the distinctive mass spectrum, black holes produced by our mechanism have other interesting properties.

At the time of formation, these black holes are non-rotating. They may acquire some angular momentum by accretion of matter at later times, but much of the accretion occurs in the radiation era, within a few Hubble times after formation, and is likely to be nearly spherically symmetric. Hence we expect this population of black holes to be very slowly rotating. It is interesting to note that LIGO observations suggest low spins for the merging black holes Hotokezaka:2017dun .

Scenarios of PBH formation from large primordial density fluctuations predict a background of stochastic gravitational waves, imposing significant constraints on this PBH formation mechanisms. Another stringent constraint comes from the observational bounds on the Œºùúá\mu-distortion of the CMB spectrum. (For a discussion of these constraints, see, e.g. Inomata:2016rbd ; Garcia-Bellido:2017aan and references therein). Our model does not require large initial fluctuations and is not subject to these constraints.

We now turn to observational constraints on our PBH formation model. Constraints on PBHs in different mass ranges have been extensively studied in the literature; see, e.g., Carr:2016drx for an up to date review. We have indicated the current constraints in Fig. 12. A very stringent constraint on PBHs with M‚àºMevap‚àº1015‚Äãgsimilar-toùëÄsubscriptùëÄevapsimilar-tosuperscript1015gM\sim M_{{\rm evap}}\sim 10^{15}\ \rm{g} comes from Hawking evaporation. For our mass function (48), a substantial mass fraction in PBHs can be obtained only if the cutoff mass is Mmin>MevapsubscriptùëÄminsubscriptùëÄevapM_{\rm min}>M_{{\rm evap}}.

As discussed in Refs.¬†Carr:2016drx ; Kuhnel:2017pwq ; Carr:2017jsz , applying the constraints to models like ours, with a broad mass distribution of PBH, requires a special analysis. For example, observations like EROS, MACHO and HSC provide bounds fmax‚Äã(M)subscriptùëìmaxùëÄf_{{\rm max}}(M) over several orders of magnitude. For a "monochromatic" mass distribution, these bounds simply imply f‚Äã(M)<fmaxùëìùëÄsubscriptùëìmaxf(M)<f_{{\rm max}}, but for an extended mass distribution they give a somewhat stronger constraint Carr:2017jsz

‚à´M1M2d‚ÄãMM‚Äãf‚Äã(M)fmax<1,superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëÄ1subscriptùëÄ2ùëëùëÄùëÄùëìùëÄsubscriptùëìmax1\int_{M_{1}}^{M_{2}}\frac{dM}{M}\frac{f(M)}{f_{{\rm max}}}<1, (54)

where M1<M<M2subscriptùëÄ1ùëÄsubscriptùëÄ2M_{1}<M<M_{2} is the range of masses covered by a particular observation. The resulting upper bound on the fraction of dark matter in PBHs (fPBHsubscriptùëìPBHf_{{\rm{PBH}}}) for different values of the model parameters M‚àósubscriptùëÄM_{*} and MminsubscriptùëÄminM_{\rm min} is shown in Fig. 13. It follows from the figure that PBHs in our model can at best constitute of order 10% of the dark matter.

Recent interest in PBHs is largely inspired by LIGO observations of gravitational waves emitted by inspiraling black holes with M‚àº10‚àí30‚ÄãM‚äôsimilar-toùëÄ1030subscriptùëÄdirect-productM\sim 10-30~{}M_{\odot}. It has been suggested in Sasaki:2016jop that PBHs in this range of masses with f‚Äã(M)‚àº10‚àí3similar-toùëìùëÄsuperscript103f(M)\sim 10^{-3} could have a sufficient merger rate to account for LIGO results.666Ref.¬†Bird:2016dcv suggested that a significantly higher PBH density was required, f‚Äã(M‚àº10‚ÄãM‚äô)‚àº0.1‚àí1similar-toùëìsimilar-toùëÄ10subscriptùëÄdirect-product0.11f(M\sim 10~{}M_{\odot})\sim 0.1-1. But recent detailed analysis in Ali-Haimoud:2017rtz supports the conclusions of Sasaki:2016jop . This PBH density can in fact be achieved in our scenario. One example with M‚àó‚àºM‚äôsimilar-tosubscriptùëÄsubscriptùëÄdirect-productM_{*}\sim M_{\odot} and Œª‚àº10‚àí12similar-toùúÜsuperscript1012\lambda\sim 10^{-12} is shown in Fig. 12.

Another interesting possibility is that PBHs could serve as seeds for supermassive black holes (SMBH) observed at the galactic centers. The mass of such primordial seeds should be M‚â≥103‚ÄãM‚äôgreater-than-or-equivalent-toùëÄsuperscript103subscriptùëÄdirect-productM\gtrsim 10^{3}~{}M_{\odot} Duechting:2004dk , and could be significantly higher. Their number density at present should be comparable to the density of large galaxies, nG‚àº0.1‚ÄãMpc‚àí3similar-tosubscriptùëõùê∫0.1superscriptMpc3n_{G}\sim 0.1~{}\rm{Mpc}^{-3}. The relevant question for our scenario is then: What is the largest PBH we can expect to find in a galaxy?

The number density of PBHs of mass ‚àºMsimilar-toabsentùëÄ\sim M is approximately given by

n‚Äã(M)‚àºœÅCDM‚Äãf‚Äã(M)/M.similar-toùëõùëÄsubscriptùúåCDMùëìùëÄùëÄn(M)\sim\rho_{{\rm CDM}}f(M)/M. (55)

For M>M‚àóùëÄsubscriptùëÄM>M_{*} the mass function depends only on the nucleation rate ŒªùúÜ\lambda, and requiring that n‚Äã(M)‚àºnGsimilar-toùëõùëÄsubscriptùëõùê∫n(M)\sim n_{G} we find M‚àº1014‚ÄãŒª2/3‚ÄãM‚äôsimilar-toùëÄsuperscript1014superscriptùúÜ23subscriptùëÄdirect-productM\sim 10^{14}\lambda^{2/3}M_{\odot}. For Œª‚àº10‚àí12similar-toùúÜsuperscript1012\lambda\sim 10^{-12} (which is the upper bound of ŒªùúÜ\lambda), this is ‚àº106‚ÄãM‚äôsimilar-toabsentsuperscript106subscriptùëÄdirect-product\sim 10^{6}~{}M_{\odot}, which would certainly be sufficient to seed SMBH.

We thus see that for some values of the parameters black holes produced by high-energy bubbles can have interesting astrophysical implications. In particular, they could seed SMBH and could account for LIGO observations.

VII Conclusions and discussion

In this paper we used numerical simulations to study primordial black holes formed by vacuum bubbles created during inflation. At the end of inflation the bubbles have a scale-invariant size distribution, and we found in Eq. (34) how the black hole mass is related to the bubble radius. Bubbles smaller than certain critical size collapse to a Schwarzschild singularity; their mass has been estimated analytically in Ref.¬†GVZ . Supercritical bubbles, on the other hand, inflate in a baby universe, and GVZ only found an upper bound on the black hole mass in this case. Here we confirmed the estimate of GVZ for subcritical bubbles and showed that supercritical bubbles nearly saturate the upper bound on the black hole mass.

Black holes in this model have a very wide mass distribution, Eq.(48), stretching over many orders of magnitude. This distribution has a characteristic mass M‚àósubscriptùëÄM_{*} and has a distinctly different form at Mbh>M‚àósubscriptùëÄbhsubscriptùëÄM_{\rm bh}>M_{*} and Mbh<M‚àósubscriptùëÄbhsubscriptùëÄM_{\rm bh}<M_{*}. There is also a cutoff mass MminsubscriptùëÄminM_{\rm min} below which f‚Äã(Mbh)ùëìsubscriptùëÄbhf(M_{\rm bh}) rapidly declines towards zero. Depending on the microphysics parameters, the characteristic mass M‚àósubscriptùëÄM_{*} can take a wide range of values, from less than a kilogram to much greater than M‚äôsubscriptùëÄdirect-productM_{\odot}.

The distribution at Mbh>M‚àósubscriptùëÄbhsubscriptùëÄM_{\rm bh}>M_{*} has the same form, f‚Äã(Mbh)‚àùMbh‚àí1/2proportional-toùëìsubscriptùëÄbhsuperscriptsubscriptùëÄbh12f(M_{\rm bh})\propto M_{\rm bh}^{-1/2}, as that predicted in models where black holes are formed by scale-invariant density fluctuations in a radiation-dominated universe Carr:1975qj . Black holes in this scenario are formed on the horizon scale, as in the supercritical regime of our model, so the coincidence of the mass functions is not surprising. We note, however, that the overdensity required for a horizon-size region of radiation to collapse is Œ¥‚ÄãœÅ/œÅ‚àº1similar-toùõøùúåùúå1\delta\rho/\rho\sim 1, and in order to form a substantial number of black holes the rms density fluctuations should be (Œ¥‚ÄãœÅ/œÅ)rms‚â≥0.1greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptùõøùúåùúårms0.1(\delta\rho/\rho)_{\rm rms}\gtrsim 0.1, much larger than that indicated by CMB and large-scale structure observations. For this reason, models predicting appreciable black hole formation from density fluctuations assume that the primordial fluctuation spectrum has an enhanced amplitude at relatively small scales (e.g., Inomata:2016rbd ; Garcia-Bellido:2017aan ).

A mass distribution ‚àùMbh‚àí1/2proportional-toabsentsuperscriptsubscriptùëÄbh12\propto M_{\rm bh}^{-1/2} is also predicted in models closely related to ours, where PBH are formed by spherical domain walls GVZ ; DGV or circular loops of cosmic string Garriga:1992nm formed during inflation. The domain wall model also has a characteristic mass M‚àósubscriptùëÄM_{*} above which black holes contain inflating baby universes. In the string model, the mass spectrum extends to very small masses and the black hole density is severely constrained by the Hawking radiation bound.

Considering the constraints from different observations, we found an upper bound on the fraction of dark matter in PBHs in our model, shown in Fig. 13. PBHs here can constitute no more than about 10% of the dark matter. Furthermore, we found that the fraction of dark matter in PBHs with mass Mbh‚àº10‚àí30‚ÄãM‚äôsimilar-tosubscriptùëÄbh1030subscriptùëÄdirect-productM_{\rm{bh}}\sim 10-30~{}M_{\odot} is ‚â≤10‚àí2,less-than-or-similar-toabsentsuperscript102\lesssim 10^{-2}, which implies that the black holes detected in LIGO events could be the PBHs of our model. With a large number of future merger detections, we should be able to infer the black hole mass spectrum (e.g., Zevin:2017evb ) and to confirm or rule out our PBH formation mechanism.

We also determined an upper bound on the mass of the largest PBH that one can expect to find in a large galaxy, Mbh‚â≤107‚ÄãM‚äôless-than-or-similar-tosubscriptùëÄbhsuperscript107subscriptùëÄdirect-productM_{\rm{bh}}\lesssim 10^{7}~{}M_{\odot}. This shows that PBHs of our model can serve as seeds of supermassive black holes (SMBH) observed at the galactic centers. There is in fact a range of parameters for which the model can account for both SMBH and LIGO observations.

Black holes formed by vacuum bubbles can have significant observational effects only if the bubble nucleation rate is relatively high, Œª‚àº10‚àí12‚àí10‚àí15similar-toùúÜsuperscript1012superscript1015\lambda\sim 10^{-12}-10^{-15}. This corresponds to the tunneling action S‚àº30similar-toùëÜ30S\sim 30, while the typical value is S‚â≥100greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëÜ100S\gtrsim 100. We note, however, that in the string landscape scenario the false vacuum has a large number (‚àº100)similar-toabsent100(\sim 100) of decay channels, and it seems likely that some of them may have small barriers with a relatively high tunneling probability.

Our analysis in this paper is based on several simplifying assumptions. To begin with, we assumed that the vacuum energy is instantaneously thermalized at the end of inflation. In a more realistic model, thermalization may extend over several Hubble times and may be preceded by a period of the inflaton field oscillations characterized by the dust equation of state. We also assumed that the bubble radius at nucleation is much smaller than the Hubble horizon.

These assumptions, however, affect only the low-mass end of the black hole distribution, Mbh‚â≤Mminless-than-or-similar-tosubscriptùëÄbhsubscriptùëÄminM_{\rm{bh}}\lesssim M_{\rm min}. Perhaps more consequential is the assumption that thermalized matter particles cannot penetrate the bubble and are reflected from the bubble wall. This is likely to be true for particles with energies lower than the symmetry breaking scale of the bubble, œµ<Œ∑b,Œ∑œÉitalic-œµsubscriptùúÇbsubscriptùúÇùúé\epsilon<\eta_{\rm{b}},\eta_{\sigma}, but at higher energies the wall may be transparent to the particles Everett:1974bs .

We also assumed that the bubble wall tension œÉùúé\sigma and the bubble nucleation rate ŒªùúÜ\lambda are constant parameters. However, this is not generally the case. When the bubble is formed, the wall tension is determined by the shape of the barrier between the inflating false vacuum of energy density œÅisubscriptùúåùëñ\rho_{i} and the vacuum in the bubble interior of energy density œÅbsubscriptùúåb\rho_{\rm b}. On the other hand, at the end of inflation the barrier is between our vacuum of very low energy density and the bubble interior. This means that the shape of the barrier and the wall tension can change significantly in the course of inflation.

The bubble nucleation rate ŒªùúÜ\lambda may also change during inflation. As the inflaton field rolls downhill, it moves relative to the minimum at œÅbsubscriptùúåb\rho_{\rm b}, so the tunneling path (and therefore the tunneling action) are also changing. As a result the mass distribution of black holes could be significantly modified and could develop a peak at the value of MbhsubscriptùëÄbhM_{\rm bh} that corresponds to the smallest tunneling action. We leave the analysis of these possibilities for future research.

[ŒæŒº‚ÄãD‚ÄãvŒºd‚ÄãœÑ]=‚àí4‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÉ,delimited-[]subscriptùúâùúáùê∑superscriptùë£ùúáùëëùúè4ùúãùúé\left[\xi_{\mu}\frac{Dv^{\mu}}{d\tau}\right]=-4\pi\sigma, (65)

where D‚ÄãvŒº/d‚ÄãœÑ=‚àÇœÑvŒº+ŒìŒª‚ÄãœÉŒº‚ÄãvŒª‚ÄãvœÉ,ùê∑superscriptùë£ùúáùëëùúèsubscriptùúèsuperscriptùë£ùúásuperscriptsubscriptŒìùúÜùúéùúásuperscriptùë£ùúÜsuperscriptùë£ùúéDv^{\mu}/d\tau=\partial_{\tau}v^{\mu}+\Gamma_{\lambda\sigma}^{\mu}v^{\lambda}v^{\sigma}, with ŒìŒª‚ÄãœÉŒºsuperscriptsubscriptŒìùúÜùúéùúá\Gamma_{\lambda\sigma}^{\mu} the Chistoffel symbols for the 4-spacetime. Right outside the wall,

ŒæŒº‚ÄãD‚ÄãvŒºd‚ÄãœÑ|out=B‚ÄãŒì001‚Äãv0‚Äãv0=A‚Ä≤A‚ÄãB.evaluated-atsubscriptùúâùúáùê∑superscriptùë£ùúáùëëùúèoutùêµsuperscriptsubscriptŒì001superscriptùë£0superscriptùë£0superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤ùê¥ùêµ\left.\xi_{\mu}\frac{Dv^{\mu}}{d\tau}\right|_{\rm{out}}=B\Gamma_{00}^{1}v^{0}v^{0}=\frac{A^{\prime}}{AB}. (66)

By Eqs. (65) and (66),

A‚Ä≤A‚ÄãB‚àíŒæŒº‚ÄãD‚ÄãvŒºd‚ÄãœÑ|in=‚àí4‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÉ.superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤ùê¥ùêµevaluated-atsubscriptùúâùúáùê∑superscriptùë£ùúáùëëùúèin4ùúãùúé\frac{A^{\prime}}{AB}-\left.\xi_{\mu}\frac{Dv^{\mu}}{d\tau}\right|_{\rm{in}}=-4\pi\sigma. (67)

On the other hand, by Eqs. (58), (61), (62), (63) and (66), we have

A‚Ä≤A‚ÄãB+ŒæŒº‚ÄãD‚ÄãvŒºd‚ÄãœÑ|in=‚àí2œÉ‚Äã[p]‚àí4‚ÄãŒìR‚àí8‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÉ.superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤ùê¥ùêµevaluated-atsubscriptùúâùúáùê∑superscriptùë£ùúáùëëùúèin2ùúédelimited-[]ùëù4ŒìùëÖ8ùúãùúé\frac{A^{\prime}}{AB}+\left.\xi_{\mu}\frac{Dv^{\mu}}{d\tau}\right|_{\rm{in}}=-\frac{2}{\sigma}\left[p\right]-\frac{4\Gamma}{R}-8\pi\sigma. (68)

Combining Eqs. (67) and (68) gives

A‚Ä≤=‚àíA‚ÄãB‚Äã([p]œÉ+2‚ÄãŒìR+6‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÉ).superscriptùê¥‚Ä≤ùê¥ùêµdelimited-[]ùëùùúé2ŒìùëÖ6ùúãùúéA^{\prime}=-AB\left(\frac{\left[p\right]}{\sigma}+\frac{2\Gamma}{R}+6\pi\sigma\right). (69)

This is used as the boundary condition in the simulations.

We can also obtain an explicit form of the equation of motion for the wall. It can be shown that

ŒæŒº‚ÄãD‚ÄãvŒºd‚ÄãœÑ|in=‚àÇœÑV1+V2+Hb‚ÄãV.evaluated-atsubscriptùúâùúáùê∑superscriptùë£ùúáùëëùúèinsubscriptùúèùëâ1superscriptùëâ2subscriptùêªbùëâ\left.\xi_{\mu}\frac{Dv^{\mu}}{d\tau}\right|_{\rm{in}}=\frac{\partial_{\tau}V}{\sqrt{1+V^{2}}}+H_{\rm{b}}V. (70)

Then by Eqs. (64), (67) , (68) and (70), the equation of motion of the wall is

‚àÇœÑV1+V2=‚àí3‚ÄãHb‚ÄãV‚àí2R‚Äã1+V2+6‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÉ‚àí[p]œÉ.subscriptùúèùëâ1superscriptùëâ23subscriptùêªbùëâ2ùëÖ1superscriptùëâ26ùúãùúédelimited-[]ùëùùúé\frac{\partial_{\tau}V}{\sqrt{1+V^{2}}}=-3H_{\rm{b}}V-\frac{2}{R}\sqrt{1+V^{2}}+6\pi\sigma-\frac{\left[p\right]}{\sigma}. (71)

Appendix B

Vacuum bubbles can deviate from spherical shape due to quantum fluctuations. The unperturbed worldsheet of the bubble wall is a (2+1)21(2+1)-dimensional de Sitter space with a Hubble parameter

H~=œµ/3‚ÄãœÉ,~ùêªitalic-œµ3ùúé{\tilde{H}}=\epsilon/3\sigma, (72)

where œµitalic-œµ\epsilon is the difference of vacuum energy densities outside and inside the bubble, œµ=œÅi‚àíœÅbitalic-œµsubscriptùúåùëñsubscriptùúåb\epsilon=\rho_{i}-\rho_{\rm b} and œÉùúé\sigma is the tension of the bubble wall. The magnitude of fluctuations of the bubble radius was estimated in Ref.¬†GV92 :

Œ¥‚ÄãR‚âà(H~3‚ÄãœÄ2‚ÄãœÉ)1/2=œµ3‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÉ.ùõøùëÖsuperscript~ùêª3superscriptùúã2ùúé12italic-œµ3ùúãùúé\delta R\approx\left(\frac{\tilde{H}}{3\pi^{2}\sigma}\right)^{1/2}=\frac{\sqrt{\epsilon}}{3\pi\sigma}. (73)

As the bubble expands, Œ¥‚ÄãRùõøùëÖ\delta R remains constant, so the ratio Œ¥‚ÄãR/RùõøùëÖùëÖ\delta R/R decreases and the bubble becomes more and more spherical. Here RùëÖR is the bubble radius.

This analysis, however, did not account for gravitational effects. When the bubble radius gets larger than the de Sitter horizon of the exterior inflating universe, R>Hi‚àí1ùëÖsuperscriptsubscriptùêªùëñ1R>H_{i}^{-1}, we expect that the shape of the bubble "freezes" and it is conformally stretched afterwards.777More exactly, we expect fluctuations of wavelength ŒªùúÜ\lambda to freeze when ŒªùúÜ\lambda gets larger than 1/Hi1subscriptùêªùëñ1/H_{i}. But here we are interested in the lowest multipoles, so ŒªùúÜ\lambda is comparable to the bubble radius. The shape fluctuations are then given by

Œ¥‚ÄãRR‚àºœµ‚ÄãHi3‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÉ.similar-toùõøùëÖùëÖitalic-œµsubscriptùêªùëñ3ùúãùúé\frac{\delta R}{R}\sim\frac{\sqrt{\epsilon}H_{i}}{3\pi\sigma}. (74)

Assuming that œµ‚àºœÅisimilar-toitalic-œµsubscriptùúåùëñ\epsilon\sim\rho_{i}, this is of the order

Œ¥‚ÄãRR‚àºœÅiœÉ‚ÄãMPl.similar-toùõøùëÖùëÖsubscriptùúåùëñùúésubscriptùëÄPl\frac{\delta R}{R}\sim\frac{\rho_{i}}{\sigma M_{\rm Pl}}. (75)

Widrow Widrow studied perturbations on collapsing domain walls and found that the fluctuation Œ¥‚ÄãRùõøùëÖ\delta R remains approximately constant in the course of collapse. We will show that this also holds for collapsing bubbles later in this Appendix.

A black hole is formed if Œ¥‚ÄãR<2‚ÄãG‚ÄãMbhùõøùëÖ2ùê∫subscriptùëÄbh\delta R<2GM_{\rm bh}. Let us first assume that the bubble energy at the moment of maximal expansion (R=Rmax)ùëÖsubscriptùëÖmax(R=R_{\rm max}) is dominated by the interior vacuum energy,

Mbh‚àºœÅb‚ÄãRmax3.similar-tosubscriptùëÄbhsubscriptùúåbsuperscriptsubscriptùëÖmax3M_{\rm bh}\sim\rho_{\rm b}R_{\rm max}^{3}. (76)

Requiring that Œ¥‚ÄãR‚â≤G‚ÄãMbhless-than-or-similar-toùõøùëÖùê∫subscriptùëÄbh\delta R\lesssim GM_{\rm bh}, we have

Œ¥‚ÄãR‚àºœÅiœÉ‚ÄãMPl‚ÄãRmax‚â≤G‚ÄãœÅb‚ÄãRmax3similar-toùõøùëÖsubscriptùúåùëñùúésubscriptùëÄPlsubscriptùëÖmaxless-than-or-similar-toùê∫subscriptùúåbsuperscriptsubscriptùëÖmax3\delta R\sim\frac{\rho_{i}}{\sigma M_{\rm Pl}}R_{\rm max}\lesssim G\rho_{\rm b}R_{\rm max}^{3} (77)

and

Rmax‚â≥(œÅi‚ÄãMPlœÅb‚ÄãœÉ)1/2.greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptùëÖmaxsuperscriptsubscriptùúåùëñsubscriptùëÄPlsubscriptùúåbùúé12R_{\rm max}\gtrsim\left(\frac{\rho_{i}M_{\rm Pl}}{\rho_{\rm b}\sigma}\right)^{1/2}. (78)

Substituting this into (76) we obtain

Mbh‚â≥œÅb‚Äã(œÅi‚ÄãMPlœÅb‚ÄãœÉ)3/2‚â°MF.greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptùëÄbhsubscriptùúåbsuperscriptsubscriptùúåùëñsubscriptùëÄPlsubscriptùúåbùúé32subscriptùëÄùêπM_{\rm bh}\gtrsim\rho_{\rm b}\left(\frac{\rho_{i}M_{\rm Pl}}{\rho_{\rm b}\sigma}\right)^{3/2}\equiv M_{F}. (79)

If œÅisubscriptùúåùëñ\rho_{i}, œÅbsubscriptùúåb\rho_{\rm b} and œÉùúé\sigma are characterized by the same energy scale Œ∑ùúÇ\eta, this gives

Mbh‚â≥MPl3/2Œ∑1/2.greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptùëÄbhsuperscriptsubscriptùëÄPl32superscriptùúÇ12M_{\rm bh}\gtrsim\frac{M_{\rm Pl}^{3/2}}{\eta^{1/2}}. (80)

This is a rather weak constraint. For example, if Œ∑ùúÇ\eta is the electroweak scale, it gives Mbh>1subscriptùëÄbh1M_{\rm bh}>1¬†kg. On the other hand, the cutoff mass MFsubscriptùëÄùêπM_{F} can be relatively large when œÅb‚â™œÅimuch-less-thansubscriptùúåbsubscriptùúåùëñ\rho_{\rm b}\ll\rho_{i}.

Bubble collapse

Let us now show that the evolution of perturbations on a collapsing bubble is similar to that on a collapsing domain wall.

Let us first consider collapse of a spherical bubble. We start with the conserved mass,

‚Ñ≥b=4‚ÄãœÄ3‚ÄãœÅb‚ÄãR3+4‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÉ‚ÄãR2‚Äã1+RÀô2‚àíHb2‚ÄãR2‚àí8‚ÄãœÄ2‚ÄãG‚ÄãœÉ2‚ÄãR3,subscript‚Ñ≥b4ùúã3subscriptùúåbsuperscriptùëÖ34ùúãùúésuperscriptùëÖ21superscriptÀôùëÖ2superscriptsubscriptùêªb2superscriptùëÖ28superscriptùúã2ùê∫superscriptùúé2superscriptùëÖ3{\cal M}_{\rm{b}}=\frac{4\pi}{3}\rho_{\rm b}R^{3}+4\pi{\sigma}R^{2}\sqrt{1+\dot{R}^{2}-H_{\rm b}^{2}R^{2}}-8\pi^{2}G{\sigma}^{2}R^{3}, (81)

where the overdot stands for a derivative with respect to proper time œÑùúè\tau. Suppose the bubble is initially at rest, RÀô=0ÀôùëÖ0{\dot{R}}=0, at the maximal expansion radius, R=RmaxùëÖsubscriptùëÖmaxR=R_{\rm max}. We will be interested in the asymptotic behavior, when R‚â™Rmaxmuch-less-thanùëÖsubscriptùëÖmaxR\ll R_{\rm max}.

In this regime, the terms proportional to R3superscriptùëÖ3R^{3} on the right hand side of (81) become negligible and |RÀô|‚â´1much-greater-thanÀôùëÖ1|{\dot{R}}|\gg 1, so Eq.¬†(81) reduces to

‚Ñ≥b‚âà‚àí4‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÉ‚ÄãR2‚ÄãRÀô,subscript‚Ñ≥b4ùúãùúésuperscriptùëÖ2ÀôùëÖ{\cal M}_{\rm{b}}\approx-4\pi{\sigma}R^{2}\dot{R}, (82)

where the "-" sign is chosen because we are considering the collapse.

The solution of Eq.¬†(82) is

R‚Äã(œÑ)=(‚àí3‚Äã‚Ñ≥b‚ÄãœÑ4‚ÄãœÄ‚ÄãœÉ)1/3.ùëÖùúèsuperscript3subscript‚Ñ≥bùúè4ùúãùúé13R(\tau)=\left(-\frac{3{\cal M}_{\rm{b}}\tau}{4\pi\sigma}\right)^{1/3}. (83)

Here, we choose the origin of œÑùúè\tau so that œÑ=0ùúè0\tau=0 at the moment of collapse; then œÑ<0ùúè0\tau<0 prior to the collapse. It follows from (83) that the total proper time it takes for the bubble to collapse is

œÑ‚àºœÉ‚ÄãRmax3‚Ñ≥b‚â≤œÉœÅb.similar-toùúèùúésuperscriptsubscriptùëÖmax3subscript‚Ñ≥bless-than-or-similar-toùúésubscriptùúåb\tau\sim\frac{\sigma R_{\rm max}^{3}}{\cal M_{\rm{b}}}\lesssim\frac{\sigma}{\rho_{\rm b}}. (84)

Fluctuations on the collapsing bubble are described by a scalar field œïitalic-œï\phi living at the bubble wall and satisfying the equation

‚àí‚àá2œï+(‚Ñõ‚àíœÅb2œÉ2)‚Äãœï=0.superscript‚àá2italic-œï‚Ñõsuperscriptsubscriptùúåb2superscriptùúé2italic-œï0-\nabla^{2}\phi+\left({\cal R}-\frac{\rho_{\rm b}^{2}}{\sigma^{2}}\right)\phi=0. (85)

The field has a tachyonic mass, mœï2=‚àíœÅb2/œÉ2superscriptsubscriptùëöitalic-œï2superscriptsubscriptùúåb2superscriptùúé2m_{\phi}^{2}=-{\rho_{\rm b}^{2}}/{\sigma^{2}}, and a non-minimal coupling to the 3-curvature ‚Ñõ‚Ñõ{\cal R} on the wall worldsheet,

‚Ñõ=2R2‚Äã(1+RÀô2+2‚ÄãR‚ÄãR¬®).‚Ñõ2superscriptùëÖ21superscriptÀôùëÖ22ùëÖ¬®ùëÖ{\cal R}=\frac{2}{R^{2}}\left(1+{\dot{R}}^{2}+2R{\ddot{R}}\right). (86)

The worldsheet metric can be written as

d‚Äãs2=‚àíd‚ÄãœÑ2+R2‚Äã(œÑ)‚Äãd‚ÄãŒ©2.ùëësuperscriptùë†2ùëësuperscriptùúè2superscriptùëÖ2ùúèùëësuperscriptŒ©2ds^{2}=-d\tau^{2}+R^{2}(\tau)d\Omega^{2}. (87)

Then, with the solution (83) the 3-curvature becomes

‚Ñõ=2R2‚àí23‚ÄãœÑ2‚âà‚àí23‚ÄãœÑ2,‚Ñõ2superscriptùëÖ223superscriptùúè223superscriptùúè2{\cal R}=\frac{2}{R^{2}}-\frac{2}{3\tau^{2}}\approx-\frac{2}{3\tau^{2}}, (88)

where the last approximation applies for R‚â™Rmaxmuch-less-thanùëÖsubscriptùëÖmaxR\ll R_{\rm max}.

The tachyonic mass could in principle lead to an instability. But the timescale for such an instability to develop is Œî‚ÄãœÑ>|mœï|‚àí1Œîùúèsuperscriptsubscriptùëöitalic-œï1\Delta\tau>|m_{\phi}|^{-1}, and we see from (84) that there is not enough time. In fact, the mass term in Eq.¬†(85) is negligible to compared to the curvature term for R‚â™Rmaxmuch-less-thanùëÖsubscriptùëÖmaxR\ll R_{\rm max}. Neglecting this term and using the approximation (88), we rewrite Eq.¬†(85) as

œï¬®+23‚ÄãœÑ‚ÄãœïÀô‚àí23‚ÄãœÑ2‚Äãœï=0.¬®italic-œï23ùúèÀôitalic-œï23superscriptùúè2italic-œï0{\ddot{\phi}}+\frac{2}{3\tau}{\dot{\phi}}-\frac{2}{3\tau^{2}}\phi=0. (89)

This has solutions œï‚àùœÑŒ±proportional-toitalic-œïsuperscriptùúèùõº\phi\propto\tau^{\alpha} with Œ±=1,‚àí2/3ùõº123\alpha=1,-2/3. The dominant solution is

œï‚àùœÑ‚àí2/3‚àùR‚àí2.proportional-toitalic-œïsuperscriptùúè23proportional-tosuperscriptùëÖ2\phi\propto\tau^{-2/3}\propto R^{-2}. (90)

It was shown in GV91 that the rms fluctuation of the bubble wall Œ¥‚ÄãRùõøùëÖ\delta R is related to œïitalic-œï\phi as Œ¥‚ÄãR‚àºœï/Œ≥similar-toùõøùëÖitalic-œïùõæ\delta R\sim\phi/\gamma, where Œ≥‚àùR‚àí2proportional-toùõæsuperscriptùëÖ2\gamma\propto R^{-2} is the Lorentz factor of the wall. (The factor of Œ≥ùõæ\gamma accounts for the effect of Lorentz contraction of bubble fluctuations.) Then Eq.¬†(90) tells us that the fluctuation amplitude does not change in the course of collapse:

Œ¥‚ÄãR‚âàconst.ùõøùëÖconst\delta R\approx{\rm const}. (91)

This agrees with the result obtained by Widrow Widrow for collapsing domain walls. The agreement between the two cases is not surprising, since the vacuum energy density œÅbsubscriptùúåb\rho_{\rm b} becomes dynamically unimportant at R‚â™Rmaxmuch-less-thanùëÖsubscriptùëÖmaxR\ll R_{\rm max}.
